16.05.text: Hi. So I'd like to talk a little bit about the people

18.47.text: who make the things we use every day:

21.00.text: our shoes, our handbags, our computers and cell phones.

24.76.text: Now, this is a conversation that often calls up a lot of guilt.

29.21.text: Imagine the teenage farm girl who makes less than

32.80.text: a dollar an hour stitching your running shoes,

35.65.text: or the young Chinese man who jumps off a rooftop

38.35.text: after working overtime assembling your iPad.

42.39.text: We, the beneficiaries of globalization, seem to exploit

46.00.text: these victims with every purchase we make,

50.33.text: feels embedded in the products themselves.

53.42.text: After all, what's wrong with a world in which a worker

55.98.text: on an iPhone assembly line can't even afford to buy one?

59.76.text: It's taken for granted that Chinese factories are oppressive,

62.41.text: and that it's our desire for cheap goods

67.50.text: So, this simple narrative equating Western demand

74.13.text: especially at a time when many of us already feel guilty

76.76.text: about our impact on the world,

79.34.text: but it's also inaccurate and disrespectful.

83.12.text: We must be peculiarly self-obsessed to imagine that we

86.11.text: have the power to drive tens of millions of people

89.28.text: on the other side of the world to migrate and suffer

94.78.text: In fact, China makes goods for markets all over the world,

97.60.text: including its own, thanks to a combination of factors:

101.19.text: its low costs, its large and educated workforce,

107.06.text: that responds quickly to market demands.

110.21.text: By focusing so much on ourselves and our gadgets,

113.26.text: we have rendered the individuals on the other end

115.72.text: into invisibility, as tiny and interchangeable

119.08.text: as the parts of a mobile phone.

122.14.text: Chinese workers are not forced into factories

124.80.text: because of our insatiable desire for iPods.

127.28.text: They choose to leave their homes in order to earn money,

130.36.text: to learn new skills, and to see the world.

134.31.text: In the ongoing debate about globalization, what's

136.70.text: been missing is the voices of the workers themselves.

142.44.text: Bao Yongxiu: "My mother tells me to come home

146.19.text: and get married, but if I marry now, before I have fully

149.91.text: developed myself, I can only marry an ordinary worker,

154.00.text: so I'm not in a rush."

156.50.text: Chen Ying: "When I went home for the new year,

159.54.text: everyone said I had changed. They asked me,

162.80.text: what did you do that you have changed so much?

165.89.text: I told them that I studied and worked hard. If you tell them

172.54.text: Wu Chunming: "Even if I make a lot of money,

178.08.text: Just to make money is not enough meaning in life."

182.44.text: Xiao Jin: "Now, after I get off work, I study English,

187.16.text: because in the future, our customers won't

188.95.text: be only Chinese, so we must learn more languages."

192.81.text: All of these speakers, by the way, are young women,

198.66.text: So I spent two years getting to know assembly line workers

201.60.text: like these in the south China factory city called Dongguan.

205.53.text: Certain subjects came up over and over:

209.96.text: what kind of husband they hoped to marry,

212.33.text: whether they should jump to another factory

216.66.text: Other subjects came up almost never, including

218.85.text: living conditions that to me looked close to prison life:

227.94.text: days and nights ruled by the factory clock.

231.28.text: Everyone they knew lived in similar circumstances,

234.76.text: and it was still better than the dormitories and homes

240.09.text: The workers rarely spoke about the products they made,

242.82.text: and they often had great difficulty explaining

249.32.text: the young woman I got to know best,

251.42.text: what exactly she did on the factory floor,

253.88.text: she said something to me in Chinese that sounded like

258.07.text: Only much later did I realize that she had been saying

264.26.text: She couldn't even tell me what she did on the factory floor.

268.12.text: All she could do was parrot a garbled abbreviation

270.58.text: in a language she didn't even understand.

274.57.text: Karl Marx saw this as the tragedy of capitalism,

278.20.text: the alienation of the worker from the product of his labor.

282.24.text: Unlike, say, a traditional maker of shoes or cabinets,

285.86.text: the worker in an industrial factory has no control,

289.11.text: no pleasure, and no true satisfaction or understanding

294.56.text: But like so many theories that Marx arrived at

296.97.text: sitting in the reading room of the British Museum,

302.62.text: Just because a person spends her time

304.92.text: making a piece of something does not mean

307.69.text: that she becomes that, a piece of something.

310.24.text: What she does with the money she earns,

313.34.text: what she learns in that place, and how it changes her,

316.85.text: these are the things that matter.

319.61.text: What a factory makes is never the point, and

321.91.text: the workers could not care less who buys their products.

328.48.text: on the other hand, plays up this relationship

330.59.text: between the workers and the products they make.

333.42.text: Many articles calculate: How long would it take

336.51.text: for this worker to work in order to earn enough money

341.81.text: For example, an entry-level-line assembly line worker

344.30.text: in China in an iPhone plant would have to shell out

347.57.text: two and a half months' wages for an iPhone.

351.12.text: But how meaningful is this calculation, really?

354.45.text: For example, I recently wrote an article

357.42.text: but I can't afford to buy an ad in it.

360.66.text: But, who cares? I don't want an ad in The New Yorker,

362.72.text: and most of these workers don't really want iPhones.

368.34.text: How long should I stay in this factory?

370.16.text: How much money can I save?

372.62.text: How much will it take to buy an apartment or a car,

375.19.text: to get married, or to put my child through school?

379.78.text: The workers I got to know had a curiously abstract

382.47.text: relationship with the product of their labor.

386.23.text: About a year after I met Lu Qingmin, or Min,

389.37.text: she invited me home to her family village

393.63.text: On the train home, she gave me a present:

396.01.text: a Coach brand change purse with brown leather trim.

400.40.text: I thanked her, assuming it was fake,

402.08.text: like almost everything else for sale in Dongguan.

405.55.text: After we got home, Min gave her mother another present:

411.55.text: and a few nights later, her sister was showing off

417.48.text: Slowly it was dawning on me that these handbags

423.29.text: and every single one of them was authentic.

426.46.text: Min's sister said to her parents,

428.92.text: "In America, this bag sells for 320 dollars."

432.29.text: Her parents, who are both farmers, looked on, speechless.

435.32.text: "And that's not all -- Coach is coming out with a new line,

437.88.text: 2191," she said. "One bag will sell for 6,000."

442.68.text: She paused and said, "I don't know if that's 6,000 yuan or

452.58.text: Min's sister's boyfriend, who had traveled home with her

457.29.text: "It doesn't look like it's worth that much."

460.12.text: Min's sister turned to him and said, "Some people actually

462.95.text: understand these things. You don't understand shit."

471.15.text: In Min's world, the Coach bags had a curious currency.

475.19.text: They weren't exactly worthless, but they were nothing

477.51.text: close to the actual value, because almost no one they knew

480.22.text: wanted to buy one, or knew how much it was worth.

484.15.text: Once, when Min's older sister's friend got married,

487.50.text: she brought a handbag along as a wedding present.

490.33.text: Another time, after Min had already left

492.50.text: the handbag factory, her younger sister came to visit,

495.64.text: bringing two Coach Signature handbags as gifts.

499.75.text: I looked in the zippered pocket of one,

501.83.text: and I found a printed card in English, which read,

514.20.text: inspired the founder of Coach to create

516.40.text: a new collection of handbags from the same

522.01.text: Six skilled leatherworkers crafted 12 Signature handbags

526.19.text: with perfect proportions and a timeless flair.

530.32.text: They were fresh, functional, and women everywhere

532.60.text: adored them. A new American classic was born."

537.94.text: I wonder what Karl Marx would have made of Min

542.17.text: Their relationship with the product of their labor

544.78.text: was more complicated, surprising and funny

549.33.text: And yet, his view of the world persists, and our tendency

552.16.text: to see the workers as faceless masses,

554.77.text: to imagine that we can know what they're really thinking.

558.64.text: The first time I met Min, she had just turned 18

562.04.text: and quit her first job on the assembly line

567.01.text: Over the next two years, I watched as she switched jobs

569.66.text: five times, eventually landing a lucrative post

572.73.text: in the purchasing department of a hardware factory.

576.31.text: Later, she married a fellow migrant worker,

578.83.text: moved with him to his village,

583.18.text: and saved enough money to buy a secondhand Buick

585.37.text: for herself and an apartment for her parents.

589.77.text: She recently returned to Dongguan on her own

592.90.text: to take a job in a factory that makes construction cranes,

596.52.text: temporarily leaving her husband and children

600.70.text: In a recent email to me, she explained,

603.28.text: "A person should have some ambition while she is young

607.33.text: so that in old age she can look back on her life

609.99.text: and feel that it was not lived to no purpose."

614.78.text: Across China, there are 150 million workers like her,

619.17.text: one third of them women, who have left their villages

621.92.text: to work in the factories, the hotels, the restaurants

625.47.text: and the construction sites of the big cities.

628.07.text: Together, they make up the largest migration in history,

631.82.text: and it is globalization, this chain that begins

637.34.text: and ends with iPhones in our pockets and Nikes on our feet

641.11.text: and Coach handbags on our arms

643.54.text: that has changed the way these millions of people

645.83.text: work and marry and live and think.

650.74.text: Very few of them would want to go back

652.69.text: to the way things used to be.

655.24.text: When I first went to Dongguan, I worried that

658.42.text: it would be depressing to spend so much time with workers.

662.80.text: I also worried that nothing would ever happen to them,

665.57.text: or that they would have nothing to say to me.

668.20.text: Instead, I found young women who were smart and funny

673.70.text: By opening up their lives to me,

676.03.text: they taught me so much about factories

678.23.text: and about China and about how to live in the world.

684.75.text: This is the Coach purse that Min gave me

687.46.text: on the train home to visit her family.

689.87.text: I keep it with me to remind me of the ties that tie me

692.51.text: to the young women I wrote about,

695.24.text: ties that are not economic but personal in nature,

699.51.text: measured not in money but in memories.

703.07.text: This purse is also a reminder that the things that you imagine,

706.49.text: sitting in your office or in the library,

710.03.text: are not how you find them when you actually go out
